titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Leviticus Lyon PapersJWJ MSS 173
titlestmt.author: by Afua Ferdnance

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 03:25

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The Leviticus Lyon papers document the professional and personal activities of the tenor singer, music conductor and choral director. Letters, writings, illustrations and photographs are included in this collection. Correspondence details the life of Leviticus Lyon from childhood to adulthood with personal letters from parents, siblings, and friends including the originally titled "world's fastest human," African American Olympic track star Howard P. Drew. Other correspondence includes letters from blues legend W.C. Handy and prominent Harlem lawyer Hubert T. Delany. The Professional Papers series illustrates Lyon's efforts in establishing the Negro Symphony Orchestra, his participation in the Annual Harlem Music Week, and his work as choral director in the Westchester Negro Choral Union. Personal papers include poems, illustrations, and other writings by Lyon.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three series: I. Correspondence, 1906-1946. II. Professional Papers, 1918-1948. III. Personal Papers, 1905-1948.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Leviticus Lyon was born on May 29, 1894 in San Francisco, California and spent most of his childhood in Oakland, California. He was born to Elizabeth Garland Lyon and Giraldo Gomez Lyon. Lyon's mother was born in the West Indies (Saint Kitts and Nevis) while his father was born in Guinea-Bissau, West Africa. His father was likely a steward, as his employment in the United States 1900 census is listed as "Stewart" and he frequently discussed life on ships in letters to his son. According to Giraldo Gomez Lyon's personal writings, he immigrated to the United States in 1880 from West Africa and married Elizabeth Garland in 1888. As a teenager, Leviticus Lyon held many jobs including elevator operator at the United States Customs Service in San Francisco, California. Lyon demonstrated his singing talent to officials in the customs department who in turn used their influence to transfer Lyon to work at the New York Customs office in 1919 to assist him in pursuing his musical education. He eventually received a fellowship to study at the Julliard School in 1925. In the course of his career, Lyon became a prominent tenor and choral director, giving performances at Carnegie Hall and St. Marks Methodist Church in Harlem, New York City. Lyon also took leadership positions in New York's music scene, assisting in the formation of the Negro Symphony Orchestra and chairing the Westchester Negro Choral Union. He lived chiefly in New York City until his death in 1958.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Leviticus Lyon Papers. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Other photographs of Leviticus Lyon can be found in Photographs of Prominent African Americans (JWJ MSS 76).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Leviticus Lyon papers document the professional and personal activities of the tenor singer, music conductor and choral director. Letters, writings, illustrations and photographs are included in this collection. Correspondence details the life of Leviticus Lyon from childhood to adulthood with personal letters from parents, siblings, and friends including the originally titled "world's fastest human," African American Olympic track star Howard P. Drew. Other correspondence includes letters from blues legend W.C. Handy and prominent Harlem lawyer Hubert T. Delany. The Professional Papers series illustrates Lyon's efforts in establishing the Negro Symphony Orchestra, his participation in the Annual Harlem Music Week, and his work as choral director in the Westchester Negro Choral Union. Personal papers include poems, illustrations, and other writings by Lyon.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Leviticus Lyon Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Former call number: JWJ MSS Lyon.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains both personal and professional correspondence of Leviticus Lyon. Correspondence in this series illustrates Leviticus Lyon's childhood in Oakland and San Fransico, California along with his rise into adulthood and professional career.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series is arranged alphabetically by last name.

did.materialspec: Photographs of Lucretia Forsyth (Leviticus Lyon's aunt), the grave of Lucretia Forsyth, and a photograph of Emil Gottsleben (friend of Lucretia Forsyth), are included in this folder.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The professional papers series documents Leviticus Lyon's efforts in establishing the Negro Symphony Orchestra, his work as choral director in the Westchester Negro Choral Union, and his career as a tenor singer. The series includes memorandums and notes from various organizations such as the Musical Art Group, as well as ephemera including programs from Lyon's singing career.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Folders are arranged alphabetically with materials within the files arranged chronologically.

did.unittitle: Certificates, resumes and work related materials

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Personal papers include various writings, illustrations and notes by Leviticus Lyon.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Folders are arranged alphabetically while materials within the folders are arranged chronologically.

did.unittitle: Registration and selection for military service
Writings of others; Sherman Morse clipping (oversize)
